title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act through a special message to Congress within 3 days of enactment. The proposed rescission cannot be reconsidered under this section or section 1012. The Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993 allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority through a special message to Congress. The majority or minority leader of the House must introduce the draft bill or joint resolution within two days of receiving the message, or any member can introduce it on the third day. The bill or resolution is then referred to the House Committee on Appropriations for consideration. The bill or joint resolution must be reported by the Committee on Appropriations within seven days of receiving a special message. If not reported, the committee is discharged, and the bill is placed on the calendar. A vote on final passage must occur within 10 days of introduction, with the House Clerk or Senate Secretary finalizing the agreement. The bill or joint resolution must be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day it is agreed to. It must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it within seven days without substantive revision. Failure to report within this period results in automatic discharge from consideration. The bill or joint resolution must be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day it is agreed to. A vote on final passage must be taken within 10 days of transmission. Motion to proceed to consideration is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on a bill or joint resolution in the House of Representatives under this section is limited to 4 hours, equally divided between supporters and opponents. Appeals on procedural decisions are decided without debate. Consideration of the bill is subject to specific provisions outlined in the subsection. Debate in the Senate on a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 10 hours, with additional limits on debate for motions and appeals. The majority leader and minority leader or their designees control the time equally. The appeal time for a bill or joint resolution is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and manager. The minority leader controls time in opposition if the manager is in favor. Additional time can be allotted by leaders during debate. Amendments are prohibited, and motions to limit debate or recommit are not debatable. The resolution can be considered in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. No motion to suspend this subsection is allowed, nor can it be suspended by unanimous consent.
